Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: GREAT COURSE. You will learn so much about really cool biological applications to physics! You learn how to reason through problems using very set models - while intimidating at first the class comes with the support to ensure you succeed!
I learned A LOT about physics and how physics exists in and fuels biological processes. Great course.
General Physics related to biology

I learnt a lot during this class. This ranged from general physics knowledge, to math skills and interpretation of in-depth questions. I did not have much of a physics background, so I struggled initially but I picked up a lot of things as the semester went on.
In this course, I learned how physics relates to biology!
I learned to think like a physicist.
Simon is a beast

I really didn't think I'd enjoy physics in college. But congrats Simon (the instructor), you did it  I really did enjoy this class, overall. I feel like I'm more able to think flexibly about difficult applications of physics concepts, and I really see the connections between physics, chemistry, and math in a way that I couldn't before. Pretty cool lineup of topics in PHYS 170, definitely worth a look.

This class was nonsense. Just a bunch of obscure math tricks. I spent way too much time agonizing over problem sets only to realize that the point was not to actually learn physics but to oversimplify everything to the point that it no longer made sense.
I learned to think like a physicist.
I am a much better student because of this class. It taught me so much about the mechanisms of diffusion, probability distributions, and medical applications like blood flow and cancer.
How to work with others for hours on end trying to solve pset problems

You learn to do more than you ever thought was possible for one class. You learn to integrate seemingly very strange concepts and work through psets with your peers. You learn to use your resources. You learn to truly "problem solve"
Basic physics concepts such as Newton's Laws but in a biological context.
You do learn how to think like a physicist by the end of it.

I honestly developed so much as a student by taking this class. The first two weeks, I went to bed so stressed every night because I was convinced that I couldn't keep up with the workload and, as a senior, I can definitely say that it was the most work-intensive class that I've ever taken. However, this class taught me how to make connections between things I didn't even realize were connected, work well with people, and adapt to stress more than I could imagine. Honestly, the effort you put in yields good results, and I feel like a much better and prepared student after taking 170. Also, I realized how much I actually liked physics. Genuinely I think it's so interesting now.

I learned a lot about how physics applies to biological systems, from epidemic models to actin polymerization. Definitely improved some mathematical skills. If you're looking for a lot of variants on a hoop rolling down a ramp, this is not the class for you.
Problem solving/critical thinking/teamwork
I learned about the intersection between physics and biology.

How to think like a physicist! Mostly how to approach a problem given the new skill sets that we learned throughout the course of the semester. It was a lot of obscure, creative thinking and problem solving.
I learned a lot about the interrelation between biology and physics, such as understanding the physics underlying motor proteins, such as kinesin, walking along microtubules.

This course helped me to conceptualize biological processes in entirely new ways. It overlapped with my physiology course on several ocasionas, and it was really cool to see the math and physics behind certain phenomena that I simply memorized as fact in the other course (such as power involved in the circulation of blood, or maximum cell size).
I learned how to think critically, question theories, and persevere!
I learned how to work more effectively and efficiently with others.

PHYS 170 taught me to think in terms of connections. A major emphasis was on the interconnectedness of physics, chemistry, and biology in the sense that laws of physics could be applied to chemical reactions and physiological processes. By the end, I was able to see the similarities between concepts like diffusion, fluid mechanics and even rates of change because the derivations of equations used similar processes. I also learned the skill of reviewing my mistakes and actually thinking critically about them because of the test corrections we were required to do.

A lot! I really credit this class with skyrocketing my ability to think like a scientist! In this class, I realized that science wasn't merely about memorizing equations, but using reasoning and logic to figure out problem-solving techniques to solve questions. I found the course very intellectually stimulating and I discovered the beauty (and the pain, often) of learning science!

I learned mechanics-y stuff, we went over lots of statistical stuff, touched on statistical mechanics: 
- conveyor belt-type stuff, but then applied to laminar fluid flow, which is pretty metal if you ask me. The highlight of the semester.
So yeah. fluid flow, steady-state diffusion in 1D and spherical. I learned basically everything for the first time, except probability things, because I'd never taken physics. I now can look at something and think up models for why it works like that, which is the best skill I took away.

I'm not sure if I learned "physics" or not, even after this semester has ended. A lot of this course is kind of "knowing" what Simon wants from you in psets/test questions. However, I did get much better with problem solving and thinking more deeply about conceptual questions themed around biology, that I would not have happened upon in a normal physics course.
I don't know how much I'll retain, but I learned some interesting applications of physics in biology.
I learned a variety of biological applications of physical concepts.

I gained insight into the fundamentals of physics, how to think like a physicist, and how to apply physics concepts to biological and medical practices. I gained knowledge in topics including but not limited to forces, momentum, diffusion, and statistics.
What can I say? Oh boy, what a class. I think I learned how to read about and understand completely novel topics, then apply them to solve problems. The ultimate figuring-shit-out course.

Really interesting topics! I very much enjoyed taking this class and learning how to "think like a physicist."  This class changed the way I thought about physics, and made it much more applicable to topics I was actually interested in.

In depth knowledge of physics applied to the biosciences and medicine, as well as how to think like a physicist. The class was quite useful because it allowed us to understand the physical principles that underlie the chemical, biological, and biochemistry principles that have been taught in our other classes. The class really allowed us to apply our other science and math skills and learn how to solve problems that were novel and crossed disciplines.
I learned a basic knowledge of physics and how to apply it to biology.

"How to take like a physicist" as Simon would say :). This course required me to heavily rely on my classmates and peers to understand the material and work through the problem sets. I had to make sure I actually understand the concepts so I could apply the knowledge to future problems.
I learned to think like a Physicist and working logically though challenging problems I had never seen before. I learned to be persistent on chugging away at problems in study hall and on my own
To think like a physicist
We learned how to Think Like A Physicist in various contexts for certain Physics-related models.
basic concepts of physics through a highly biomedical lens, I had never taken physics formally before so much of the material was new to me.
I was able to obtain a solid base on physics concepts and how physics applies to many subjects in biology.
I learned how to use a new way of thinking to solve problems.

I learned so much in this class its actually crazy. I feel like I truly learned how to think like a physicist and how to use the knowledge I have in various scientific fields in order to approach real life problems.

I learned how to apply basic concepts of physics to biological situations. I learned how to develop simplistic models of life processes that can be described in mathematical and physical terms. I gained a greater understanding of Newton's Laws and how principles of statistics and random walks underlie biological systems.
Understanding of basic physics concepts, problem solving skills, ability to collaborate with peers
A strong background in physics, I learned how to think like a physicist.
I learned so much through this course, and it was actually much more applicable than I had imagined. Highly recommend this class!
I learned many applications of physics to biology.
I learned how to apply physics to biological questions. It was a refreshing way to learn physics.
How to use basic physics concepts to approach problems you wouldn't traditionally see in an intro physics course; and overall how to use logic to solve scientific puzzles
I learned a great deal about physics and how physics is applicable in many different fields of study.
The course could be improved by either decreasing the problem set requirements or teaching the concepts more to where the problem sets are solvable without begging a TA or Simon for the answer..

Weaknessess: Very long and drawn out PSets, Confusing structure of course (topics didn't flow), amount of time involved outside of class, bad lecturer (Simon)
Strengths: TAs, Structure of course

Study halls are my life! Having the opportunity to work through problems with the aid of the professors or TAs was SUPER conducive to learning. That being said, please ensure that there are enough TFs per study hall so students don't have to wait in line for 45 minutes to get clarification.

Study halls are definitely a strength - collaboration with classmates and the help of Simon (who is great) and the TA's (who are also great) make the psets doable!

The course is also extremely organized. There are updates canvas (daily) which means you will never miss a deadline and always know what you can be working on. 


A weakness is that the course is very fast paced. If you don't get one thing (say in lecture) you fall behind immediately. The psets take an awful lot of time.

I really like the study halls. I honestly have so much fun doing work with others, don't tell anyone. I think the sense of collaboration comes from the fact that there isn't a curve which makes this course so much better! Additionally, the content is actually kind of cool when you come to understand it. I really think you guys did a good job. I like that the problem set questions are application based, but not tested as much so that we get to appreciate cool theoretical models but then not be ambushed with them on the test.
Simon is the #1 strength of PHYS170; he really cares about the material and his students.
No weaknesses,... simon is just too much a beast to have any weaknesses... awesome dude... awesome prof... this is the only assessment I've ever done... he's that good hahah

Strengths: interesting bio/physics intersections addressed, fair midterm questions

Weaknesses: incredibly high pset workload (to the point where one starts to question whether taking this class/spending this time is worth it, and honestly after the whole semester I still think a lot of the pset questions *weren't* worth the exhaustion), disproportionately difficult final exam (compared to midterms)
Use a textbook. It's ridiculous for students who engage with the material in class and study halls to still have no idea on even where to start the problem set, not to mention the midterm.
I thought that overall the course was quite cohesive and well run. Some of the homework problems seemed unrelated to the material at times, but overall, no real flaws.
I was not a big fan of the study halls for the most part but I think Im unique in that regard. Everything else was perfectly suited to me.

Strengths: Working with other premeds encouraged a collaborative work environment, and I definitely had great opportunities to meet more people through that

Weaknesses: Lectures are unclear and disorganized, instructor doesn't place himself in the mindset of students, expectations for assessments do not match what's tested on psets
You learn material you didn't think you could learn. However, this takes a tremendous amount of time. To truly understand this course, you will need to commit your life to it.

Lectures correspond with the textbook, so it is easy to go back and learn something. The psets are collaborative which is a good thing because they can be very time consuming. I guess the only weakness is the discrepancy in grading among TAs. My friends and I all had different TAs with different grading styles.
Problem sets seemed unnecessarily hard at times and almost impossible to do without going to a study hall/peer tutor.

The real strength of this course was the instructor. I can't say enough good things about Simon. And the TAs! And the peer tutors! Simon knew my name in a 100 person lecture, and was at almost every study hall. I can't imagine this course without him, nor can I imagine the level of student dedication without him. I was blown away by how much he cared about students. I could literally go on and on. The material was well organized and segued into each segment nicely. I'm not even sure what a weakness would be, other than that maybe the introduction to module 1 was a little overwhelming, but I think that was more a factor of my lack of experience with math/physics than anything the instructors can can control.

Strengths:

Simon Mochrie is great and cares a lot about the students and the class. TAs were similarly wonderful and helpful. Study halls are amazing - go to every single one of them until you finish your pset, because I found that I learned the most from working through the problems with my peers. The one time I decided to skip on that, I felt like it hurt me a lot on the following exam. So go to study hall. The class isn't difficult if you reach out to people to help.

Modules are well-written and good supplementary material.

Don't stress too much about quizzes because he gives a lot of opportunity to make up for missed grades.

Exams are fair; make sure to do practice exams and psets thoroughly.

Weaknesses:
At times it felt more like math than physics (ex: eigenvectors). Sometimes the pset answers seemed like they were coming out of nowhere, especially conceptual questions. I also felt like sometimes lectures were confusing, especially derivations. Also ln = log was weird to get used to.

Super collaborative! I am the biggest introvert alive and I was forced to make friends to finish my psets. No complaints on that though, because I met a bunch of great people through this class that I would have never otherwise interacted with. Weakness is the phrasing of questions. You kind of have to get used to Simon's wording.
One strength is that there are many support resources and study halls where I could get help.

Though many people have complained about the way that intro physics are taught in general, it is clear to me from this past semester that no radical changes have been done to improve it. The only thing that really works in favor of the students is the grading system/scale which is very helpful, but the actual method for teaching is poor at best. There were many times when I felt like the TAs were unhelpful. The peer tutors were much better as were my fellow classmates. The worst part was that the psets and tests were not indicative of what had been taught in class. I understand that physics is a difficult and very technical subject, so it is hard to try to come up with a good way of getting students who may not be interested or may not be good at this subject, to really understand the processes and the material. I think that the way we are in taught in lecture does not prepare for the level of difficulty presented in the psets and tests. Though the things we learn in class are difficult, the processes re relatively logical and if the psets and tests followed this same template, they would both be more helpful and more doable. But as the class is now, the psets are ridiculously difficult and require a lot of steps that do not further your knowledge of the topic at hand, but just take a lot of time, i.e. intensive algebra and simplification for some problems. Another thing that I noted was that the tests would present new situations and a different way of thinking that had never been introduced in class. I, for one, do not have an intuitive grasp of physics and unless I have been shown how to solve a certain type of problem or been shown the process, I won't just be able to produce the reasoning out of thin air during a final or midterm. I understand that we do not have enough time in lecture to cover every single topic and every single type of problem that one may encounter that would go along with the topic, but I do not feel like the psets or quizzes helped to introduce me to a problem even like this to make me feel prepared for the tests.

Study hall is life changing and absolutely necessary. I cannot thank our teaching staff (especially Simon!!) enough for the amount of time they put into helping us learn physics. The Monday quizzes are a good way to keep on top of the material. Lectures were sometimes a little dry and disorienting especially when the slides didn't match what we were doing (so that when I went back to look at the lecture slides they weren't very helpful). That being said, the modules are extremely helpful and well written.

One strength of the course was the overall transparency. The expectations were laid out clearly such that students were pretty much always notified about their progress in the course and what they needed to accomplish to ultimately obtain the grade they desired. The grading was also fair, which was much appreciated. A strength and weakness of the course was the study halls. Although learning from one's peers was proven to be very beneficial in this course, study halls tended to be understaffed. Thus, it was often difficult to obtain the help you needed in a timely manner, given that three professors/TAs can only help so many students at once. For this reason, it would be great if more TAs and peer tutors could be present during the study halls. In addition, the problem sets were a weakness because completing them on a weekly basis was a very, very long, arduous process, and the questions were often phrased very strangely. Although Physics is notorious for having students do long problem sets, it would be great if the problem sets could be slightly shorter in order to enhance students' learning of the material. Doing about 10 problems each with 5-7 sub-sections causes a great amount of weekly anxiety that could be improved by having students do less problems.

This course is great in its encouragement of collaborative thinking and exploration of observable phenomena through physical law. I really enjoyed connecting with my classmates and learning together. I think the level of application of concepts sometimes unfairly exceed what was presented in lecture, and sometimes the TAs were even unsure of how to deal with certain concepts without consulting he answer key repeatedly. However, while psets were often a bit of a nightmare, they also sometimes posed fun challenges to complete. I also really enjoyed the active learning through clicker questions, and think that could be further integrated into the course in the future.

I liked how bio-focused this course was since I'm really not a physics/math person but I really didn't think the lecturing style was the clearest. The psets were often unreasonably hard and seemed more intent on testing our math skills and endurance than they were physics concepts. They were basically impossible to do without lots of help. The midterms were reasonable but then the final was much more difficult, which I found inconsistent. In addition, the course seems quite disorganized--students often had to remind instructors to upload materials/fix typos which I don't think is their responsibility. They said they were very open to feedback but I don't think much work/thought has been put into improving this course.

Strengths- great way to work with other people, concepts build on one another and can be understood 
Weaknesses- concepts could be presented in a more clear format

This course was interesting and very well taught, but it seemed to be more like a mathematical modeling course, rather than a straight physics course. A lot of the concepts were similar or the same as concepts from Math 116 taught by John Hall. I spent probably 10 hours on the psets every week, and spent a lot of my energy on this course. The final exam was still difficult though.

Strengths 
- Designed to be collaborative and not competitive. 
- Module notes are beautiful and self-explanatory. 
- Simon really cares about the student experience

Weaknesses
- Way too much investment of time and energy required when placed in the context of four or five additional courses that students are concurrently taking, especially considering it is an introductory course. 
- Simon could have been better prepared for lectures to go more smoothly.

Strengths: very challenging, intellectually stimulating. Simon was a great professor, very supportive. You can tell lots of thought and effort were put into the slides and presentations. I really liked the themes of the class. Very great collaborative environment. I've never met a teacher who cared so much about his students doing well like Simon does- the effort he puts into the class, from the notes to answering Piazza to staying till 10pm on study hall nights is remarkable and I found his support system to be the reason why I marginally was able to survive in the class.  

Weaknesses: Simon often went by very fast, so it made keeping up a very difficult task. Sometimes the themes seemed very niche, but that was ok.

Strengths: topics spread across modules. It's really cool to apply random walks and diffusion and probability in so many ways.

Weaknesses: To me, it's kind of silly that for some pset answers, the only way to get the answer is from a TA/ULA in study hall.

The strengths of this course are of course, the TA's, peer tutors, and course instructors who are all very happy to help you if you encounter problems with psets or exams throughout the semester. Most of the learning came from doing said psets and practice problems, not so much lecture. As a result, I feel that attending lecture didn't so much add to my knowledge as much as just reading the modules did.

The study halls were very useful. However, the quality of the teaching fellows was definitely a downside to the effectiveness of study halls and review sessions. They were unprepared for the study halls, and would sometimes give us the wrong answers because they didn't understand what the problem was asking.

It is VERY hard to grasp physics concepts that can be applied to several scenroios when so many concepts we learned in class were tied to specific examples. It was also hard because much of the course hinges upon student interactions and some people (like myself) are not comfortable with working in groups or working with new people.

The strength of this class above all is its commitment to helping students learn. I am honestly incredibly impressed by the level this took; the class is uncurved which is initially intimidating but negates competition, plenty of opportunity is given to learn from past mistakes (we were able to recover 50% of points lost by submitting thoughtful revisions evaluating our errors), and there is ample opportunity to interact with classmates, TAs, peer tutors, and even Simon. The set hours for study hall were so incredibly useful, especially with a group of people--the psets are moderately lengthy and often hard, but most weeks it was possible to finish them during study hall hours (cumulatively 7h per week max). The two midterms were quite fair, although the final was unexpectedly difficult. The only weakness is that once in a while, Simon would lose the class in confusion halfway through lecture, but this wasn't especially common. In general, it was very well organized to facilitate learning throughout the entire semester.
I appreciated how much Simon cared about our learning.

The strengths of this course were its lecturer and the design of the course. Simon was a fantastic professor, who brought energy, humor, and knowledge to the classroom. The class was designed to foster collaborative learning through group work, study halls and even peer tutor sessions. In order to succeed in this class, I had to work harder than any other class, but what made it easier was knowing that my peers were in the same boat. We worked together to solve problems and learn from one another, which created a positive environment.

Lecture was difficult to follow, especially with math involved. Learning happened outside of the classroom through reading the modules, which were usually comprehensive and great. Problem sets are another beast, however. I think it's great to challenge us and have us be engaged with the material, because often times it makes physics fun, or at least rewarding. However, I think everyone would benefit from shorter problem sets. Perhaps more relevant problems and fewer ones that require TA help would make them so much more tolerable. Otherwise, the course is well organized and the time Simon and the TAs put in is admirable.

Very organized course with a fantastic professor!  Professor Mochrie was a definite strength- you can tell that he really cares that his students do well.  The coursework was also extremely interesting.  A weakness is that the workload was a little disproportionately high, but I had expected that going into the class.

The attitude of the professors, the high attendance by both teaching staff and students at the study hall, and the problem set/midterm organization made the course very successful. I felt that the professors really cared about the students succeeding and really wanted to help us understand how to get the problem right and were thus willing to sit and work with us to make sure that we understood. I felt that the lectures were the part that needed to be improved the most. Many times he would skip steps or go very quickly through hard parts of the problem. Because the lecture would go over the same problems as the notes, I felt that they were sometimes not very helpful and it would be better  if the professor went slowly through the key concepts that were necessary to solve the problem. The p-sets and midterms and quizzes made sure that you were keeping up with the material and did not fall behind.
Modules were amazing, so helpful for student learning. Accessability of answer keys was dope, and access to all past lectures was killer. Simon nailed it.

This course was well structured to provide the support students needed in a caring environment that improved morale. I was happy with the way it was taught, save for the fact that lectures were paced much too quickly. The professor would make miscalculations in his haste, which would make themselves evident at highly inconvenient and costly later points in time.
This course was very well organized with the course material. The study halls and problems sets were very helpful in learning the material.

This class uses biological and medical applications of physics, which makes it quite interesting for pre med students in the class. The teaching staff is readily accessible, which makes it easy for you to get help when you don't understand concepts. Lecture can move very quickly, so it is important to follow up the material after class to really grasp it.

Studyal Hall is essential and really helped facilitate my learning. Same with peer tutors. It just takes initiative to go every single week even if you dont feel like it because hear reapurces help so much.
So much support and opportunities to learn
Strengths: study hall is very helpful, Simon is very available, lecture is interesting. Weaknesses: Very time consuming course
There are many resources to do well on the problem sets, but sometimes the material is taught too quickly.

I actually really liked how the course was designed, especially with the study halls that encouraged everyone to work together on problem sets, etc. I think that some of the lectures went pretty fast and Simon didn't do a great job explaining some things, so it required a lot of independent engagement with peer tutors, TAs, etc to fully get a grasp on certain concepts.

The Psets I thought were great to have due on a weekly basis since I forced you to keep up with the course material, however, I think they took nan extreme amount of time to complete compared to other classes. Maybe assign one or two less problems?
I loved this class. I really enjoyed the study halls, as I think my understanding of material would have been much lower without them. I also thought the lectures were taught really well.

Strengths: Professor Mochrie. He is dedicated and eager to help his students succeed. 
Weaknesses: Never enough TAs at study hall which was sometimes incredibly stressful

Strengths: extremely high engagement of the professor and his willingness/eagerness to help his students succeed, some cool derivations of concepts I learned in other classes (Michaelis-Menten, kD, Gas Law, Gibbs Free Energy equations were especially interesting), fair midterms and generous points-back policy, quizzes to keep me on top of the material, multiple opportunities to seek assistance at study hours from classmates and teaching staff

Weaknesses: very limited engagement of TAs besides as homework helpers during study hours--I would prefer an option for a traditional discussion section every week to review all the material covered, unreasonably difficult and complicated problem set questions that were nearly impossible to answer without seeking help from staff, an unclear mix of highly specific mathematical derivation and unrealistic simplification of biological processes
I really enjoyed the frequent study halls and office hours. They facilitated learning and encouraged students to engage with the material. The subject material was very interesting.

Strengths: A very well-structured course, dedicated instructors. 
Weaknesses: Very fast pace, requires lots of engagement outside class time.

There are many resources available so that students can get the extra help they need. However there seems to be too much material covered, it would be nice to spend the extra time to do more examples and really master the material.

This course has many strengths - Simon, the instructor, is wonderful and so dedicated, the material is interesting for the most part and the psets bring everything together and help you for the exams. The downside is the amount of time you must put in for a 1 credit class, which can make you neglect your other classes.
Homeworks are too long to promote learning. Grading system was very fair however. Not enough focus on intuition, too bogged down with math.

The strengths included lectures and the peer tutors. One way that the course could improve is if problem sets had more questions on fundamental concepts (That are meant to be done outside of study hall) so that students can grasp key concepts before they tackle difficult questions. Also, the course would greatly improve my assigned study-hall groups.
This class does a great job at getting students involved and providing support.

I loved the study halls. It was a very collaborative environment, and I feel that the study halls are where I learned physics. It was great to work together with my peers and work through problems and have nudges in the right direction from the TAs, professor, and peer tutors.
Interesting and unique material; sometimes not super clearly taught, although this improved by the end of the semester

The study halls were extremely helpful and took away a lot of stress that I had about the course. I would improve the course by perhaps using different examples than those from the module notes during lecture, as when we did do this, the additional examples greatly helped me learn how best to apply the lesson.

GREAT COURSE. You will learn so much about really cool biological applications to physics! You learn how to reason through problems using very set models - while intimidating at first the class comes with the support to ensure you succeed!

This course has a VERY heavy workload. It is not easy. That being said, it is by no means impossible. Just set aside a lot of time outside of the class to teach yourself the material and do the PSETs, and you will be fine.

Great class for pre-meds who have to take physics! I hemmed and hawed about this class versus physics 180 but I am SO GLAD I went with 170! Everyone works through psets together until you all really understand the problems, so you are united on the struggle bus. Also, Simon is great at explaining things clearly so that you feel very prepared going into any exam or quiz. You do have to put in the time to attend study halls in order to do well, but it is worth it to easily get an A on all the problem sets and feel decent about exams. Also, Simon really wants us to feel good about the course, so any time we don't do well, he lets us correct the exam/quiz for half credit back, which makes you enjoy the course and actually want to learn from your mistakes rather than resent it.

Definitely if you are good at math, have a little physics background and if you have an interest in medicine (e.g. how the body works etc).
You also need to be willing to put in the time, it is by no means an easy class, but it is doable. You also get 50% corrections back for midterm 1 and midterm 2.
Over physics 180 any day!
Take this course. Seriously. It's super good, and it really will help you understand biological concepts better in a physics framework.
YUP

I have no regrets about having taken PHYS 170. Solid professor, friendly work environment, lots of collaboration between friends/new friends, fascinating topics (not just saying that  I was genuinely astounded at times, especially near the end), etc. etc. The only drawback is the workload, which honestly is probably about the same in PHYS 180. So just try PHYS 170 and stick with it, particularly if you have a group of friends/friendly faces that you know will be there in solidarity for the semester.
Take 180. The problem sets taking absurdly long amounts of time, the midterms are near impossible, and at the end of it all, you realized that you didn't even learn physics.

Yes, this is a good class. Sometimes you'll probably hate physics, but there are always plenty of resources for help, and if you go to study hall, you'll actually make some friends too believe it or not.
Yes. Excellent class that will not only help you in your understanding of physics but also all of the other sciences too.
If you're a premed studying for the MCAT, take 180-- it's much more useful

I think it takes a certain kind of student. Be ready to put work in. Be ready to sit with uncomfortable topics that you won't ever fully understand. Be ready to be overwhelmed. You will get through, but part of you might die inside trying.
If you have no physics background and are pre-med, I recommend that you take this class.

You probably need to take this class if you're taking it, so good luck. I will say that Simon seems to really care about his students, but that doesn't make the class any easier. Some exam questions seem unnecessarily convoluted and the workload is a bit too intense. But you do learn some things so I guess it's ok. Good luck

This class takes so much time. The content was interesting, but I did not appreciate that the psets took so many hours every week, especially since some of the problems weren't helpful in understanding the concepts. That being said, the TAs and peer tutors put a lot of time into the course, and study halls are essential to completing the psets. The exams were fair and the test corrections make it even better.

I would. I mean you're probably taking it vs. 180, but I think that if you're pre-med or just interested in biology and like nice people and want instructors to care about your success and wellbeing and learn some interesting things and be challenged and rise to it and feel like you could be a physicist. Simon put just as much work into the class as the students did, and he created a wonderful community.

I would recommend this to people who didn't like the traditional physics concepts, and/or are interested to see how physics applies to the real world. Overall a great class that really help me learn and is really set-up to benefit us. No tricks involved.
Pretty fun physics class, and not too difficult, especially if you come in with a physics background. People seemed generally happier in the 170 area of the Teal classroom than the 180 area lol.
Yes, I thought it was a great introductory course for people interested in how physics is applied to biology.
This is a requirement for many majors and pre-med, so I know you have to take it and I'm sorry.

I would recommend this class to any premed student looking to take physics. It teaches you to incorporate what you've learned in biology, chemistry, biochem, and physics and engage with material you already know in a new way. The type of problems we learn to solve are relevant to the MCAT. The course is a lot of work, but any physics course is. PHYS 170 has these study halls 3x a week which are optional but outrageously helpful. It facilitates collaboration with your peers and allows you to ask all questions you may have in a casual setting. The TAs, peer tutors, and professor Simon are all great. Overall, if you are premed and want to take physics, I would highly recommend this class.

I would only take this course if absolutely necessary; if you just need a SC credit, there are much easier and digestible courses to pursue. If you are in between this and 180, I would suggest shopping both. Both are going to be difficult, so it shouldn't be a matter of which is easier but rather which seems more interesting/better suits your specific learning needs. For instance, if weekly quizzes help you obtain a better grasp on the material and the interwoven nature of Biology and Physics seems appealing to you, 170 may be a better fit.

I would recommend this course to a student choosing between 170 and 180 if they found themselves principally drawn to exploring biologicala rn chemical concepts and not pure physics. The class had a lot of sections that were based on statistics and algebra, rather than the heavy calculus focus of many pure physics courses, and I personally enjoyed that.

I definitely wouldn't say I recommend it, but if you're looking into it you probably have to take it. As a bio/pre-med focused person, I definitely enjoyed this more than I would have 180, but I don't think it's a very good course. The psets are unreasonably hard (and filled with arbitrary concepts and math that seem unrelated to what we do in class), the modules/lectures hard to follow and disorganized, and the tests are inconsistent in their difficulty level. It doesn't seem like much work was put into this course, to be honest--most of the TAs (not all of them though) were unapproachable and instructors often had to be reminded to upload assignments and other files. All this in combination made for a really frustrating experience, and it was also grating to be shown weird inspirational videos at the beginning of the semester and told that all our problems with the course were because we didn't have a "growth mindset" or whatever when every classmate I knew worked really hard and were still frustrated by the way the course was set up.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student. Simon and the teaching staff were always there to help students. Grades were communicated clearly throughout the semester. The course was very well-organized. Professor Mochrie really wants everyone to do well. While the course can be challenging at times, there are ample resources to seek out help and overcome almost any challenge.

If you want traditional physics, then take Physics 180. If you want to learn more digestible concepts relating to biology and physics, then this is class is better for you. You're going to definitely be working on psets for 12-15 hours each week no matter which class you take. I think the information in this class is more enjoyable to learn than just traditional physics. Also, Simon is one of the most caring and dedicated professors I have ever had at Yale, and he will definitely help you if you reach out.

If you're reading this evaluation, I assume that your are required to take physics. If you're pre-med or have a particular interest in the biological sciences, I would recommend you take this course over PHYS 180! I actually was dreading taking PHYS 170 as a senior and thought it would be the most awful experience. It was  a pleasant surprise when it became one of my favorite classes! If you just allow yourself to be amazed by how Simon elegantly demonstrates the relevance of physics to physiological processes or even epidemiology, you will actually begin to think physics is cool! Woah! 

Seriously, though, don't be scared of this course! You just have to invest a lot of time and energy into learning in PHYS 170. Outside of class hours, you will likely spend 7-8 hours on physics. Here is a sample weekly schedule that may help physics seem less overwhelming:

Saturday (2 hours) - Review the most recent module and make a one-page summary guide. Take a quick glance at next week's pset problems. 
Sunday (0.5 hours) - Review the material that Simon says will be on the quiz in particular. 
Monday (1 hour) - Weekly quiz in class; Take a stab at 1 or 2 pset problems out of like 9 
Tuesday (3 hours) - Go to the study hall and try to at least attempt every single pset problem. The peer tutors and TFs are clutch in helping you through roadblocks. 
Wednesday - Take a break!
Thursday (1 or 2 hours) - Go to the study hall and polish up your pset!
Friday - The pset is due. 

To prep for the midterms and final exam, be sure to really go through the practice problems he gives you well in advance and then go to a peer tutor's office hours to work through any problems you're still struggling with. Sometimes the same exact question on a pset or practice exam shows up on the real exam!

Yes, unless you love your GPA and want an easy class, in which case no. I personally love a challenge. To be fair, the class was difficult and it was a gruesome challenge. It's expected that you spend 10+ hours on the class on the weekly problem sets, and the material was often very hard and the abstractions difficult to understand. But after pushing through it for a bit, you figure out what to do and it becomes manageable, albeit still difficult. Most challenging class I've taken at Yale, but definitely the one that has pushed me the most to excel.

If you're interested in biological stuff, it's probably worth taking this over 180. As someone who never took physics, the added biology layer - while sometimes annoying - was at least curiosity-inducing.

I would most definitely recommend this class over 180, as study hall is a great resource used by many of the 170 students and the psets are easier (and take significantly less time). In 170, you learn plenty of the basics of physics without having to deal with the weird "clique"-yness of 180 (premed students suffer together and stick together in 170). Some of the material was difficult (but you get 50% of points back with corrections on midterms) and some of it was actually interesting. If you don't particularly like physics and are hoping to do well, this class is a good balance of individual and group learning/cooperation that you will likely do well in and learn something in the process.

If you're deciding between 170 and 180, I would say go for 170 if you don't have a strong physics background, as I heard 180 goes much faster and may be less forgiving to those coming in with a weak background.  This class has a host of people (peer tutors, TA's, and even the course instructors) who are all there to help you if you encounter problems. That said, 170 really kind of just teaches you problem solving more than giving you a strong knowledge in physics.

I can't say that I enjoyed or liked this class, but taking it instead of 180 was the best choice for me. 170 is a doable class if you put the time into it (which for me meant going to study hall for 5-6 hours a week) and I think it's easier than 180 (although I'm not sure how useful the material from 170 will be in the future).
No!

I honestly would. It's a challenging class, don't get me wrong, but going in with that expectation meant that I was pleasantly surprised by the amount of support students get. Simon and the TAs and peer tutors definitely care about teaching the concepts well and making sure students understand them, so while my time commitment to this class was quite high (the highest of all my classes this semester), the work put in was reasonable and relatively painless (subjective to a physics class I guess). I do recommend this class.

If you've taken physics in high school and are using this to fulfill a requirement, maybe take 180. There's almost no overlap from AP Physics and the concepts are overcomplicated by being put into biological context.
I would definitely recommend taking this course. Simon is really amazing, and I appreciate how much he cares about our learning.

While I would not recommend physics for those uninterested in STEM classes, I would definitely recommend this course for those needing to take an introductory physics course. The course was challenging, but it was also highly rewarding because of the challenge and effort needed to succeed. I learned a lot about physics, of course, but I also learned about the importance of self-reflection in learning, collaborating with peers, and how to think in a different way.
If you have to take physics as a pre-med student, might as well take the one that tries to incorporate biological processes-- makes physics way more interesting.

Definitely take this class if you need an introductory physics class!  I was deciding between PHYS 180 and this course, and I am so glad I chose PHYS 170.  While I have no doubt that PHYS 180 was also a fantastic course, as a pre-med/MCDB major, I was much more interested in the topic material of PHYS 170.  Both classes are difficult, so if you know it's going to be hard, at least choose the one that would be more interesting to you!  I could not get myself excited about spinning objects and blocks sliding down ramps, but I could definitely get myself interested in blood vessels and geckos and donuts and infections!

Yes!! If you are pre-med or a biosciences major definitely take this course over PHYS 180. This course makes physics so interesting and it many times doesn't even seem like you are doing physics, just that you are learning the concepts and the statistics behind the biochemistry concepts that you've already learn or will learn. The student atmosphere is super supportive and both your peers and the teaching staff want you to succeed and are trying to help you succeed as much as possible.

Would totally recommend this class. I was super dreading it because I didn't take physics in high school, and it didn't even suck at all! Simon even bothered to learn my name!! Take a lesson chem department. 
Seriously though, very fair tests, difficult psets but a ton of help to complete them, corrections on tests, practice tests given, lectures uploaded, and supporting modules to organize your learning.
I would recommend this course to another student because it is extremely interesting to learn about physics in a biological sense
If you're not pre med, do not take this class. This class is heavily biology based, which is great for premed.
This course is the best yale college course I've taken
I'm glad I took this course over 180. I actually enjoyed physics.
I would. It is very thought provoking and interesting. This course provides much more realistic models that pre-meds might one day encounter in their studies and careers.

If you need to take physics for pre-med, this is not a bad option. A lot of it came from the fact that nearly the entire course was pre-med juniors, so there are guaranteed to be a lot of people you know and would want to work with. If you don't need physics/already have a strong background, I would take 180 since I think the workload might have been a little less without weekly quizzes, but there was less group engagement.
I would definitely recommend this class to another student, especially if you are premed because it makes learning physics fun due to the biological applications.

Absolutely. The course does require a lot of work, but it is worth it. It also doesn't feel like as much work as it is, because you are working together with classmates and have help from the teacher and TAs.

Yes! This course is difficult, no lie, but Professor Mochrie goes out of his way to make sure that every student feels comfortable with the material. Also, the content of the class is incredibly interesting!

If you're a premed, I would recommend Physics 170. Simon is a highly engaging and enthusiastic instructor, and the material is very relevant to other courses you must take, particularly chemistry and biochemistry. The examples in class are easily applied to biological systems, unlike in Physics 180, in which you might wonder why the material you're learning is relevant to you. Be prepared for a tough workload, and make sure you have a group of people to work with (though there are always classmates at study hours to befriend). However, you'll feel very accomplished at the end.
Yes. I enjoyed this class significantly more than my friends in PHYS 180 did.

Definitely would recommend as an intro physics class for pre-meds over PHYS 180! The applications were so much more interesting and made the very long psets much more enjoyable. There is so much support available in this class, from Simon to the peer tutors and TFs, which make learning the sometimes difficult material very doable if you go to study hall every week.
problem sets suck but if you do all the work its fine.
I recommend it to anyone who is pre-med and does not have a strong physics background.

I would take it over 180, if you don't know any physics (like me). It was painful though. Everyone spends obscene amounts of time doing the work for this class-- I have NEVER spent so much time for a single class before (I'm a junior). Every weekly quiz is a new heart attack. They are EXTREMELY generous about grading for tests.

If you are a biology major, pre-med, pre-vet, or anything else health related, you should take this course. This course is for those who wonder what physics has to do with medicine. The problems are designed to understanding biological concepts at a physical level. This course requires a lot of time spent working on problem sets outside of class, but the study halls are worth attending. I would recommend this over PHYS 180.

Yes I would. For someone interested in life sciences, this course offers some unique applications of physical concepts that kept me engaged throughout the semester. Teaching is perfectly adequate as well.

I would recommend this course to another student interested in any of the life sciences, as it involves a great width of information that is incredibly useful in those fields. While it may seem like a major challenge, there are plenty of resources available to make sure that you are able to learn the material.
